Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  Glick, Henry
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick!

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry is probably the best TA I have ever had. He was always accessible and always went above and beyond in his explanations/ help over email and in person. He is really knowledable about the topics over just knowing what to type in R. His feedback on the homework was especially helpful and definitely helped me improved my stat skills.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Extremely responsive to student questions and knowledgeable of subject matter. A great resource.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry Glick's excellence performance as Teaching Fellow was unparalleled in my F&ES experience. He was clear and organized throughout, providing detailed feedback on every assignment and offering thoughtful guidance on building knowledge through each course topic. Henry always made himself available, was proactive in explaining complex issues, and encouraged students to improve themselves. Henry worked harder than any TF at F&ES.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry gave exceptionally thorough, useful and timely feedback on assignments. He always made himself available for assistance with R.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was a fantastic teaching assistant. He was incredibly responsive over email and always available to answer questions in office hours. He explained confusing concepts clearly and efficiently and was very approachable. He also provided extensive and very helpful comments on graded assignments, which I am certain was very time consuming but I found invaluable in helping me improve throughout the course.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry is the best TA I've had at Yale. He was extremely responsive and very comfortable with the material. He shows a clear dedication for his job and truly helped me gain comfort with the marerial.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was incredibly helpful as a TA. He responded to emails very quickly with detailed answers. He was always available to answer questions and did his best to help.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I was very frustrated with Professor Gregoire's lectures. He is thoughtful and supportive teacher, and clearly an expert on modeling data. However, the lectures did not emphasize important ideas or concepts on each occasion; instead, they were like chipping away big topics piece by piece. This made it difficult to understand and remember the key ideas we did cover (splines, mixed effects, etc).

I learned a lot in the course but there was sometimes a bit of a mismatch between the material covered and the assignments. I think I would have felt more confident if we'd had more, smaller homework assignments beginning earlier in the semester. It was also sometimes challenging to gauge how much of the statistical concepts I was grasping when they weren't as necessary to apply on the assignments. Having an in-class examination would have been a useful benchmark of how well I understood the theory of the course.
Professor Gregoire is clearly very passionate about the subject matter. I did struggle at times with his lecturing style, but he was effective overall.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The homeworks were very useful to understanding the concepts. We had enough time to do them which is really important for R when you can get stuck on one piece of code for a while. The lectures were a little difficult to sit through without getting a little lost or distracted but the notes were great.
Homework assignments were a good way to implement concepts covered in class.

The seven problem sets were appropriately spaced and provided a meaningful iterative process to help students learn the material. As TF, Henry Glick's excellent topics were very helpful in fine-tuning my knowledge and process over the course of the semester.

The homework assignments are very useful. They gradually increase in difficulty. Tim is a great lecturer, and makes dry material accessible and engaging. I expect to be referring back to Tim's lecture notes and scripts for years to come.
I enjoyed working on the assignments and putting rubber to road in R. I thought the modeling techniques we learned were interesting and useful.
I learned how to use R! I am certainly no expert, but I really do feel comfortable with the program basics and the statistics involved.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The instruction of the course was not very engaging. Lectures were primarily a recitation of class notes and read directly from a projected pdf. It's fairly dry subject matter taught in a dry manner.

Class lectures were difficult to follow. The 80-minute lecture is a challenging format to maintain attention. It would be helpful to have specific, short reading assignments completed in advance to compliment the lecture. Or, assign students to introduce a topic (or summarize an idea) once or twice each during the semester. The course slides are well-meaning but do not stand on their own. It would be helpful to improve the slides by emphasizing takeaway messages and action steps. I also suggest adding a weekly section to review the week's lessons and review R code and methodology carefully.
I really enjoyed working through scripts with Professor Gregoire in class. I would like to see more of this during lectures.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Statistics and visualisation is a necessary and valuable skillset in the environmental field. R is the best package out there right now, and this course gave me valuable practice with it.

I plan to purse the specialization in environmental policy analysis and this course was helpful in building a foundation in statistical analysis which I believe I will need. I am also now working with YCELP and they were looking for students with experience in R so I hope to continue building on the skills I learned in this course.
This course gave me the tools needed to analyze data, as well as the confidence to interpret the analysis of others. This is an invaluable skill.
This course is helpful for building quantitative skills.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Thought it would be useful to incorporate regression modeling into my research
To gain graduate-level training in statistics and R.

I had taken statistics and econometrics as an undergraduate but my quantitative skills have absolutely become rusty in the intervening years. I was hoping to jump back into statistics to prepare myself for higher-level coursework.
I took this course to learn how to use R, and I'm very pleased with all that I've learned.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, definitely!

No, I didn't learn much from this course. The professor wasn't engaging enough to make lectures interesting and homework assignments were largely an exercise in copying scripts already provided. There was little real interaction with the material.

No. I gained exposure to new topics relevant to ecology and forestry data, but I found fewer applications to the social sciences. I am grateful for the opportunity to understand new concepts (e.g., mixed effects, nonlinear regression) but do not feel like I gained competence to apply these approaches.
The material in this course far exceeded my expectations.
I still have a ways to go in becoming comfortable with R - I was still relying quite heavily on example scripts for the final project. I think I just need to take more courses using the software.
Yes! Definitely.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I worked on my problem sets with a friend in the course and it was invaluable to trouble-shoot R questions and approaches to the questions with another person. I highly recommend having a homework buddy!
Yes, unofficially. I worked with a partner on several homework assignments, and I found this to be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take notes on the PDF notes!
Consider taking a class in R prior to taking this course.

Take a different course. The R course (FES 720) provides a better introduction to using a statistical programming language. If you insist on taking FES 753, this course covers different approaches to regression modeling and is valuable to ecological and forestry data. I do not recommend it for social science students. Be sure to consider other courses beyond FES in the Statistics Department, the School of Management, or the School of Public Health.

Take it. You're unlikely to find such an accessible treatment of statistics anywhere else. This course will also increase your confidence and expertise with R and statistics far beyond simple regressions.

I would recommend reading over Tim's lecture notes after every class and speaking with him or Henry with questions early on. Tim's notes are very dense but extremely helpful, but I sometimes needed a few reviews before I really understood what was going on. Don't be afraid to ask questions - Tim and Henry are both very approachable and can help make sense of what seems impossible!
Do it! Pay attention in class, and go to Henry often. He is an excellent resource. Also, ask questions!
